nodes.bodyText:
Don't like it, but I needed this for the test.
This is not public API, so we should be good.
Ok. Someday we need to talk about merging ConstraintStreamSession and ConstraintStreamScoreDirector to avoid unneeded indirection :)
This is the test that checks, for a sufficiently complex stream, that the ordering is correct.
This is not consistent with equals().
All node indexes are unique now. Therefore this fail-fast makes no sense anymore.

Crap, ideally when a node is replaced by a sharedNode, it doesn't take up an extra nodeIndex.
Because it does, the nodeSize will be actually bigger than the number of actual nodes in place. (so it shouldn't be called nodeSize indeed and a comment should specify that strange behaviour). So the queue will have a number of empty spaces. Actually, that hurts performance...
... so we need to recycle nodeIndexes of nodes that get shared. Maybe upon sharing, call BuildPolicy.undoNextIndex() that does nextNodeIndex--?
This is not an issue. Node indexes are perfectly sequential, they are never duplicated. (The "+1 trick" takes care of that.)
Actually, this is now just nodeSize (the number of nodes), I'd argue. Wdyt?

I wouldn't write this as an else if because the 2 conditions are unrelated and it creates the confusion that they are.
Suggestion: replace the else with a line break. - because the sharedNode check is a quick return (special condition for which the main content of this method doesn't apply).

(important)
This is very wierd.
I would expect the it take as the next Index from the buildPolicy.
This way the next Index doesn't increment. That's a bug I think?

The index is incremented immediately after this, when the node is checked for sharing. There is a test that checks for this.
I am interested in counter-examples.
No. This appraoch won't work with composition approaches. For complex networks we can't predict the gaps.

Assuming that Group is always preceded by a GroupBridge, this is perfectly safe.
Otherwise I'll need to see an example of a network where that is not the case.

No. The entire algorithm depends on the fact, that nodeIndex is only ever actually incremented when node sharing is ruled out. It makes the algorithm incredibly simple and effective - no need for any sort of rollback.

This is heavy. Thankfully it is only ever used in BavetConstraintSession constructor.
Considering that it gives us a fail-fast on a pretty important thing, I say we need it.
100% agree that it is worth it.
Not useful anymore. We now have a better test, and that one checks the node indexes directly.

By removing it, this test also doesn't run on CS-D any more?
+0 to remove if it's fully duplicate for Bavet, including the actual scoreCalculation verification (which seems to be the case).
Your call.
If we do keep it, maybe it should be renamed to something like "nodeIndexChallenger" or "joinFilterLeftBridgeVersusJoinFilterRightBridge"? Idunno.

CS-D never had node indexes, we need not worry about these things there.
Everything else this test does is covered elsewhere.
Interesting approach by pushing that here. It's inline with the rest of what Bavet currently does, so +1.

Adding that zero is strange. Use at least 16 (or better yet the default): the memory cost of 16 is triviial, especially as only a handfully policy elements will exist, while the cost of sharing 9 nodes will be quite significant already.
By the way, due to from() filtering on initialized variables only, there is pretty much always node sharing.
So my advise is to remove this line's change.
Why is the distinct needed on the nodes? I'd argue if they are not distinct, then node sharing is broken and we want it to fail fast.
Motivation: grammar ("the", etc) and show the node index in that error message if we have it available anyway.
